text: The snow never ceases.
The snow is infinite.
Cold deep in the bones.
Snow stinging the eyes.
Colder than cold.
Snow and snow and snow and snow.
Snow, then snow, and snow again.
One ski in front of the other.
The scenery blurs into itself.
Just keep going...
Wind like encroaching walls.
An infinity of ice.
An eternity of winter.
Cold finds its way into everything.
Keep moving. There is no other choice.
Gravity controls me completely.
Snow like static in the ears.
The trick is to never let yourself stop.
An all-encompassing sense of chill.
Nothing to do but ski and survive.
Snow shrouds everything around me.
Ice encrusting everything in view.
The slope will end in time.
If I only focus, I'll get out of here faster.
Snow that deafens and numbs.
How far down can this slope go?
The slope around me is so impossibly uniform.
Before me is more of the same.
A world of nothing but ice.
Each breath takes more effort than the last.
There are no landmarks anywhere.
But they said this was the best skiing anywhere.
There is only one option: keep skiing.
Everything freezes before my eyes.
The reward for braving snow is more snow.
I ski on autopilot, outside myself.
Cold beyond cold. Cold as in absence.
The farther I go, the steeper it looks.
Movement behind me; a noise. Whoosh, colder breeze, dusting up of snow. But when I turn, nothing.
My legs would ache if I could feel them.
Half the trees are splintered dead.
No time to shiver.
An unnatural buzz to the wind.
A thousand ways to describe the cold.
Selective sensory deprivation.
Chill down to the nerve endings.
If I close my eyes I'll crash.
If I don't keep moving I'll freeze.
I have to keep breathing.
Was that ski lift there before? And was it empty?
Where have all the people gone?
Why did I agree to do this?
Could anyone even find me out here?
A snowboarder passes by with a confidence I lack.
Every element is its own pummeling force.
Air that annihilates.
The people passing by all look the same.
A man whizzes by with impossible, inhuman speed.
These people leave no footprints. Nor do the skis. Nothing leaves a mark.
Somewhere I hear the bark of a dog. Ahead of me? Behind? I can't tell the difference.
I don't remember when I started holding my breath. Something is holding it for me.
Do I have any skin left to go numb?
The scenery looks like a snowglobe: picturesque, inescapable.
The trees must be moving.
There were supposed to be more signposts.
There were supposed to be more people around.
Nothing looks like what the map said.
Fog hangs in the air. At least I think it's fog.
The weather was supposed to be cold. But not this cold.
I had imagined this place more inviting.
The snow looks unnatural up close. Too reflective, maybe. Impenetrable.
Impossibly high.
Flying, or flailing.
From the air, the ground seems impossibly far away.
I have to stick the landing.
Somehow the presence of ski jumps is reassuring.
Something out of my control propels me forward and up.
I flail through the air, out of control.
Can't let myself fall.
Is this the part where I feel free?
The slope looks far too vast beneath me.
I feel myself moving faster while airborne. Is that good?
I have to trust there's flat ground below. I can't look down.
Moving on wind and momentum alone.
Every movement airborne feels so impossibly precarious.
The wind's too loud up here. It wants me down.
Face meets snow.
I don't see what hit me until it's too late.
I lie motionless, half-frozen.
Have to get my bearings. Can't get them.
I've got no control over my body.
Limbs topple over swaddled limbs and I'm facedown in the show.
Every time I fall I fear it's the last.
The crash doesn't hurt exactly. It's more that I know it should.
Every crash makes me weaker.
The snow gives way like a sudden sinkhole.
Another skier whizzes by my downed body. He doesn't even notice.
Despite myself, I yelp. I hear the words escape my lips. But I hear nothing.
Going back feels wrong.
I fight gravity to pull myself back uphill.
It takes all my energy to hoist my skis upward and go back.
Every step half-undone by gravity.
None of the ski lifts acknowledge my struggling upward.
I'm backtracking, yet nothing above me looks familiar.
Turning back like this is pointless.
I don't know where I'm going or why.
And for what? To ski back down?
I can't find the footprints I left behind.
I try to find my way back to the main slope.
The top of the slope seems so far away.
The uphill trek seems so much steeper now.
Nothing good awaits here. I have to go back.
Sunset threatens. I have to go faster.
The trip uphill is agonizingly slow.
I'll never reach the top at this rate.
Every millimeter seems to take hours.
Gravity slows and sedates me.
Full speed ahead.
The scenery whizzes past, a blur.
Momentum carries me farther and farther.
I ski straight down, as fast as my body allows.
I could go faster.
I don't need to ski straight down.
I ski at a slant, not fully downhill.
Steady lets me survive.
Endless slope in this direction too.
If I go faster I might crash.
Everyone else here seems so impossibly fast.
Turning takes more and more effort.
I fight to steady myself as I turn.
I move in a winding path.
I can't focus on skiing straight.
I'm maneuvering around something, but I can barely see what.
The snowfall keeps me down.
Eventually I know I have to get up.
Maybe a break will restore me.
The slope passes me by.
The slope looks infinite when viewed from the ground.
Gravity could keep me down here forever.
I'll get up if I feel ready.
I pause to catch my breath. But it remains the same.
Did I really think stopping would help?
A few minutes, and it already feels like I've been out here for hours.
No watches are allowed here.
I just hope this will be over quick.
If only I remembered what time it was.
I don't have a way to tell time. Just my internal clock.
I don't know how long I've been out here.
It feels like I've been skiing forever.
Every minute seems to last hours.
Time has no meaning out here. Just motion.
Have I been skiing for an hour? Two hours? Two days? It all feels the same.
My sense of time comes and goes.
I have no watch. I just sense it.
Or something like that.
It already seems so long.
My sense of time keeps me focused.
I cling to this sense of precision.
No one told me what a normal amount of time was.
Time was shaky enough as it was.
Time no longer registers for me.
I could have been here minutes. Hours. Days.
I just know it's still not dark.
Time is an illusion out here.
All I know: moving faster, moving slower, unmoving.
Or something like that.
And meters and meters to go.
Is that all?
Such a small number, on paper.
I feel each meter in my aching bones.
A wasteland of ice now.
I won't say I'm lost. I can't.
The farther I go, the quieter it gets.
Still no end in sight. Nothing.
Surely I should have seen the bottom by now.
The route is far behind me. There are no routes anymore here.
It all feels wrong.
I don't want to be here anymore.
I long so much for warmth.
Snow gives way to fetid slush.
Footprints, but not in a pattern.
I'll never ski again.
I no longer remember the sensation of warmth.
Ski lifts keep heading upward. All full. None for me.
The only way out is down. Right?
I could die out here.
Another dog trots by. Or is it fleeing?
Freezing to death suddenly seems so possible.
The air sends spines to my face.
I become acutely aware of every new gradient of cold.
The world around me seems to close in, to move against me, impenetrable.
The snow seems denser here. Deep like quicksand.
No chance now of anyone finding me. It's too far.
I try to remember the outside world. I remember nothing.
Snowdrifts arranged like open graves.
My peripheral vision is gone. Just tunnel vision forward.
Perverse, empty nostalgia for the slope before.
I feel my skin go numb, unresponsive.
Wind sounds like shrieking, when there's enough of it.
My body doesn't ache exactly, and yet it feels like it should.
There are scents now, each more acrid than the last.
It occurs to me that the slope wants me gone.
A bush is burning. Don't think about it.
Snapping, shuffling sounds in the distance, growing with every meter.
Another sound: a bark, possibly from a dog. There is nothing else it can be.
Every tree I pass looks battered, gangrenous.
Snowdrifts start to look like chasms.
The air around me sounds like it's hissing.
An unending expanse produces its own kind of claustrophobia.
The colors are sickeningly bright against the snow. Too bright to be real.
I feel constricted in these clothes. Like they're slowly strangling me.
The only thing more unsettling than a darkening sky: a sky that never darkens.
I can't stop moving. The snow will swallow me, I know.
If anything happened to me, the snow would bury any trace.
Screaming will make it worse.
The landscape is atrophying, and so am I.
Is death warmer than here?
I learned once the conditions under which a human could freeze to death. Some things you don't forget.
The snow begins to chatter. It must be the snow. There is nothing else.
The footprints don't look like footprints anymore. They look like trails. Like being dragged and leaving marks.
I start to think about my will. Before today I couldn't have told you the last time I'd done that.
All I remember are crashes.
The thought makes me wince.
But I'm still moving.
Crashes are normal and to be expected. So I was told.
My aching body tells me all I need to know.
Mustn't think about my battered bones.
I'm covered in snow. That's answer enough.
I can't dwell on skill. I have to keep skiing.
Born for it.
Practically a professional.
Peak skiing performance.
The surge of confidence keeps me going. Another meter at least.
I can still do tricks, it seems.
Somehow I'm still upright.
Small comforts.
Until the next crash.
I have to find comfort in this.
How does one even know?
But out here there's no way to know.
As if anyone's keeping score.
The only thing I have a sense of is passing time.
I'm skiing. That's enough.
I just have to trust the skis.
It's not like tricks matter.
If I ever reach the bottom, maybe I'll ask.
Why?
Anything as a distraction.
If it keeps me moving...
The only thing that keeps me going.
I won't find the end unless I focus.
But skill won't save me.
These little habits I've already learned.
What I should ask is whether I'm still alive.
Another missed turn...
I thought I'd be able to make these turns.
Every turn missed makes me lose track of time.
The sign I passed flashes a loud, disorienting red. Another turn missed.
I can't turn on cue. My body's too stiffened by cold.
A searing light from the sign behind me that makes me stumble.
I contort my body until maybe it'll turn on command.
The movement the turns require is impossible, inhuman.
run away run away run away
run away run away run away run away
ANOTHER ONE IS COMING
THE TIME HAS COME
THEY ALWAYS FIND THEIR WAY HERE
THIS ONE IS RECKLESS
THERE ARE MORE OF US THAN YOU
WE SEE YOU REGARDLESS OF ALL
THEIR SKIS SOUND LIKE ANTICIPATION
EVEN THEIR MOVEMENT SATIATES
NOWHERE WE CANNOT REACH
JUST LIKE THE ONE BEFORE
WE ARE WHERE YOUR EYESIGHT ENDS
IN THE END THEY'RE ALWAYS DRAWN
THEIR COMPULSION TO SEE IT TO THE END
NO ESCAPE NO ESCAPE
ANY MINUTE NOW
No one told me it would be this quiet. No one told me that when all sounds cease, you hear the snow. You never stop hearing it.
A sign tells me how to gain better control. But I don't understand what it's telling me.
They briefed me on the symbols for the difficulty of slopes. Green circle, easy. Blue square, medium. Black diamond, hard. Every ski slope has one. But this one didn't.
All they told me about this slope was that it was free. Free of charge. Free of rules. Or free as in falling.
A finger goes numb. Then another. The numbness creeps up my arm and further down my body, in a strange pattern I can't quite place.
The slope was established in 1991, according to a sign. Who did it? What was here before? Was it anything?
Out of the snow appears a ski lift. Inside are two men. They stare blankly and still. The snow moves more than they do.

I think about the fact that a person created this place, laid it out and scattered the snow and cut the trees and smoothed the slope and invited the world. They would want it to be safe. I have to remember that.

Ski slopes generate their own snow when weather forbids. Sometimes, if the sky is clear and you listen closely, you can hear the whir of the generators in the background. Yet the sky is clear, and I hear nothing.
Lift towers jut into the air: attached to nothing, occupied by nothing, anchored by nothing. And yet there are always lifts.
I remember peripheral vision. A 360-degree world. A world with more than these two things: forward, and snow.
All my senses collapse into the same sense: cold, movement, nothingness.

On ski slopes all landmarks are manmade, so these rocks must be manmade too. But they don't feel planned. They jut out of the snow at violently irregular intervals, like something punching its way free.
The tree stumps are too neat. Somehow inorganic. Clean decapitations everywhere.
A man drifts past me. His eyes are dead. I can't say for certain the rest of him isn't.
I never really thought about gravity before. But gravity feels heavier here. It feels like what it is: a force beyond you pressing you into the earth.
I pass something with a foul, unplacable odor. It smothers me, far longer than it should. But when I turn around, I see nothing. Not even a footprint. Just stench.
Out of the corner of my eye I see something seeping through the ice, an unnatural color. But when I look back it's gone.
A man topples over and falls fast. Something in his movement unsettles me, but before I can place it he's there and gone.
The slope is less and less uniform the farther I go. Rougher, darker snow. Dead branches everywhere. Icicles beneath the snow like fangs.
Something moving underneath the snowbanks. Some sort of protuberance, something from deep below. I can't look back.
A woman freezes. From a tree, a tendril. Tendrils around the skis, the hair, the rest. And then, snow.
